name: Ayoreo

rows: See 'body' 04.110, which forms a minimal pair with the above.
sin filo, mocho, desafilado, embotado, romo
Also 'kučaa kũ'reei 05.510. Egg shell is 'kučaa-kũ'reei a'ooi 04.120; egg white is uka'gooi.
A small f.; also 'kuča-a'sige; a large f. is po'n̥aa-ŋe, means 'blown up'.
Also ka'nii-raai; ka'nii-ree, lit. 'generous'; oo'm-i, oo'me 'good temperament'.
ãaka'rãai means 'long hair'; 'short hair' is gaa'tuui.
Also i'meenu-i; i'meenu-a; 'daača-n̥ai; 'daača-n̥a, with much mud.
For pronouns: include bound/cliticized pronominal forms where significantly different from the free forms
Refer to position. See 04.331. Reference to motion, ahaʔ; tahaʔ; -ahaʔ; -jaʔ.
Meat flour is ã'rii; m. roasted on the coals is ago'taa-i; m. that has little blood iboo'r-i; iboo'r-e.
Refer to a person. An 'old thing' is i'haroo-i; i'haroo; 'kučaa-i'haroo-i; 'kučaa-i'haroo.
Also čo'm̥ara-i, indicated by the thumb on the right hand.
Also koni'nii-n̥ai; koni'niin̥a. 'Bright red' is gaa'tii; ga'tii-a.
The latter is an animal path. A 'cart trail' is yu'pidi.
A tap root is ee'ri-keruui, cf. 12.550. Other roots that entwine are ee'ri; r. of fallen tree is 'kuč-ee'ri.
'It is r.' tara'taʔ. 'To be r.' pu'n̥ui; pu'n̥ua 04.441; verbal form is oo pu'n̥uik.
See 07.250. Also pahoga-'di; pahoga'de; and 'short but strong' tu'nu-i; tunu-'ŋe.
Lit. 'up, above' 12.080. Also 'gee-ode 'ueečaai; gaa'tee-odeʔ. Lit 'the other side of the clouds'.
Varies with kukara'ni, which is larger.
Also naɲoo'raa-i; naɲoo'ree. 'Thick and round (like a squash or stick)', tutu'tude-i; tutu'tudi; tutu'tude 12.810.
Refers to a person. Also ki'yigitaa-i; ki'yigitaa-ge 05.123 'ripe'.
Respectively: verb; adj.; adj. Also gadi'o-godeʔ; gadi'o-ge-dieʔ.
Also means 'eat' 05.110. To chew for another is ũ'tirẽʔ; 'one who c. for another' is ũtira-'soorĩ; ũtira-'ŋoori; ũtira-'to.
To c. corn, manioc, beans alone or with meat.
Also i'hooča-gaay; d. to bury is ihoo'ča-meʔ.
Also means 'chew' 05.180. To eat without leaving any for somebody else is i'ŋara-meʔ; iŋa'ra-meʔ. To eat something tabu is a'gu gaai.
Means to stumble, fall. To fall inside is ĩi'koorã-haʔ. To fall from above is i'baaseʔ.
Also e'dogesaa-i; e'dogesaa-ge; verbal form is u'čere-ŋaay.
The latter is 'squeeze the body'. Also imi'neseʔ. 'To wring again' is ipaati'gaseʔ; 'to w. a hyssop of honey' is i'hoseʔ.
Lit. 'nurse (suck milk). To s. honey or a liquid is i'peseʔ; u'muna (05.480); 'one that sucks much' is are'ko-n̥ai; are'ko-n̥a. See 'sexual intercourse' 04.670; 'prostitute' 19.720.
Also geen̥aa-ri'ŋeei; 's. with much pain and itching' is 'ŋii-riŋai; 'ŋii-riŋeei.
See 05.560. Also ĩiri'gi-hi yoo'di gaay 10.470; the sound of one swimming is čo tũ tũ.
Also iiti'ŋaareʔ; to throw with force is een̥a-'pusu.
'To tie up an animal' is a'di-haʔ.
The latter two mean 'to walk to'. 'To walk in' is ĩiri'gi-hiʔ 10.660; to walk with shoes on, is uu'čie 'yiriidaa-deʔ 06.510, 10.431; to walk barefoot is uu'čie n̥u'mi 01.212, 10.431.
Means 'grasp my surroundings'; cf. 15.710, 11.140. 'Hard work' is un̥u'si yu 'omeʔ, means 'feel very comfortable with'; 'to w. with eagerness' is oo yuhu'ɲa-meʔ, means 'to punish myself' 21.370.
The latter refers to 'a little farther'.
goo'si te e; goo'to te e
Of a bird. Wing of insect is ãra'ma.
To perspire from a fever is hũ'rua gaay; see 'body' 04.110.
Also čoo 'tidi 'tidi; čoo 'tigi 'tigi. First form also means 'throb'.
daa'te is 'mother', with the meaning of 'big'. Also oro'ko.
A small bird. A large bird is ču'ŋuperĩ.
mitu, montete (Peru), paujil/panjuil (Peru), paujil de Salvin (Peru for Mitu salvini)
Northern Amazonia (N of Solimões), not in northern Colombia; Dark-winged trumpeter is found south of Solimões
Different types have different localized ranges
Also digoro'ko-n̥ai; digoroko ke'de-n̥a-i; huusi'ei; uusi'ei.
loro real, loro (Sp. form is a loan from Carib)

Small green, yellow, red parrot. Small blue p. with yellow beak is sirooga-'bi-a; small red p. is tiiya-'bi, čii'ya-'bi; cf. 03.831; small green p. is suaka'ra; small yellow p. is suakara ke'de-n̥a; small green p. with blue tail, yellow beak and wings is
Also giidobooi; kuuku'huu-daa'te, augmentative -daa'te. Also kuuku'huu-dai-'n̥a-i.
Lives in the rocks. Also 'koboto. See 03.832.
Also n̥aa'ko-n̥a, domestic duck. A water duck is n̥aa'ko-yike; a small water duck is kučibohaa-i. kučaa is 'thing'.
sachaperro, Perro de Monte, Zorro Vinagre, Guanfando; Zorro Ojizarco, Zorro Negro, Perro de Orejas Corta
oso hormiguero; tapia pelejo or pelejo chico for Cyclopes didactylus
Myrmecophaga tridactyla (giant anteater); Cyclopes didactylus (silky anteater)
armadillo, carachupa (Peru), yangunturi (Peru for Giant armadillo)
family Dasypodidae; e.g. Priodontes maximus (Giant armadillo), Dasypus novemcinctus, Dasypus kappleri
Melanosuchus niger, Caiman schlerops; Paleosuchus sp.
Port term reportedly borrowed from Tupi
maparate (used in Peru for some types of catfish, including Auchenipterus sp.), cunchi (used in Peru for some types of catfish), bagre (catfish)
iguana' is reportedly from Arawak iwana
An edible stingray. Nonedible is 'dika-če'ke; cf. 03.130.
boa; mantona (red-tailed boa); boa de altura
A poisonous s. is nasaa'miroi. Tobité dialect is asaa'rio. A black s. is u'gaa-gadooi, lit. 's. that goes'.
Yellow-footed: Geochelone denticulata; Red-footed: Geochelone carbonaria
Downstream of major rapids and waterfalls
Edible m. is hupa-'ŋoori, in the N̥upedo Goosodeʔ dialect.
Mature forests of Rio Negro and Upper Amazon
may be confused in some entries with O. bataua
moriche (Col, Ven), aguaje (Col, Peru), achual, miriti
Brazil, Bolivia, Colombia, Ecuador, French Guiana, Guyana, Peru, Venezuela; in and near swamps
pui, irapay, hoja de irapay, caraná
Mauritiella armata OR Lepidocaryum tenue (irapay), Mauritius carana
Mauritia carana is limited principally to the Rio Negro and Upper Orinoco regions; dry catinga forests
chontaduro (Col, Ecuador); pipire (Col); pijuayo (Peru), pijiguao (Ven); tembe (Bol)
ungurahui (Peru), palma de seje, milpesos, patabá
mostly north of Equator; common in Amazonia
may be confused with O. bacaba - compare entries
secondary scrub vegetation. lower alt. of eastern Andes
Gossypium (barbadense: long fibers; hirsutum: short fibers)
ceiba, huimba, lupuna (Peru for Ceiba sp.)
northern South America and central America; common in disturbed areas
Capsicum sp., principally chinensis and frutescens
maní (may be loan from Taino Arawak), cacahuete
caña flecha, caña brava, caña isana
banano, banana, cambur, bellaco, variedad de plátano
'unoro is a water plant with leaves like the banana leaves.

Also ku'gee ča'ki-peei; white b. is kugee ke'de-n̥ai; short b. is ku'gee-pitai, lit. a small bean; lima b. 'koyabe-n̥ai; vine b. is ku'gee-i ba'haai, lit. first b.; ku'gee-i ne'haai; ku'gee-i du'guu-taai 10.472, a climbing vine.

Refers to hard c., 15.740. Sweet c. is edo pa'rataai, 15.750; yellow sweet c. is edo 'sarẽ-i 15.690; popcorn is 'geen̥a-pitai 12.560; blue c. is ugare-'tei; c. on the cob is 'geen̥a u'po-i, 15.680; shelled c. is geen̥a'ɲ̥u-nieʔ; 'geen̥a-pina'su-i; sparce
secondary scrub vegetation and indigenous gardens
Secondary scrub vegetation and indigenous gardens. North and South America (Brazil, Peru, Bolivia, Suriname, Colombia)
secondary scrub vegetation and indigenous gardens
tortuga caspi, pretina (Peru for tree and tumpline); carahuasca (Peru)
Duguetia sp. OR Fusaea longifolia OR Guatteria chrysopetala
castanha do para (B. excelsa); castanha de cutia (C. edulis)
Bertholletia excelsa [cf. Couepia edulis 'castanha do cutia']

1) Couepia: restricted area within Brazil, Rio Purus basin and middle Solimões.  2) Bertholletia: elev: consistently about 200m; mature forests. Widely distributed from Peru, E. Colombia, Brazil to Nicaragua.
anarcado, castaña de cajú, nuez de la India, marañon, cajú, merey (Venezuela)
secondary scrub vegetation and indigenous gardens
tree; most sources will not distinguish between occidentale and other varieties
jagua, majagua - Colombia, caruto, xagua - Venezuela, bigrande - Bolivia, huito, yaguayagua - Peru, ygualti - Nicaragua, maluco - Mexico
native to NW Amazonia, found primarily in Vaupes and Caqueta regions
other species of Pouteria exist and have much-used edible fruit; these can be subsituted where relevant
uva de monte, uvilla (Peru), puruma, caime, caimarona (and variants; Col.)
grows wild in Western Amazon basin; cultivated in Colombia since pre-Colombian times
a tree; not a true grape

not generally cultivated in western (subAndean) Amazon. Arroyo-Kalin (2010) argues for a correlation with distribution of dark earths, mostly formed after 1AD, and the modeled-incised pottery tradition.

Provides more starch and is more pest-resistant than the sweet variety, but requires much processing. Arroyo-Kalin (2010) proposes that bitter type was developed from sweet through post-ceremic agricultural intensification (motivated by high starch yield
Primary staple in western/subAndean Amazonia, less important elsewhere
No processing required, but lower starch yield and pest resistance than bitter variety

calabazo, calabaza; auyama (Dominican Republic and Venezuela), ayote (parts of Central America), zapallo (parts of South America), tutumo/totumo/totuma (Cresc tree), huingo (Peru for Crescentia cujete), tapara
Crescentia cujete (round variety - tree); (Cucurbita) Lagenaria siceraria (bottle variety - vine)
Also bahu'tasi; baru'tasi, latter used for houses. A vine used for killing fish is ere'nai.
secondary forests and secondary srcrub  vegetation
semi-domesticated, native to Amazonian basin, esp. NW
Large black ant (with painful bite)' [isula(?)] is dii'ti. 'Small brown ant (with painful bite)' is diiti ke'de-n̥ai. 'Umbrella ant' is ga'n̥oo.
bullet ant, lesser giant hunter ant
conga, hormiga yanabe (Colombia), isula (Peru), Hormiga Veinticuatro
Colombia: zampopo, hormiga arriera; Venezuela: bachaco; Peru: curuhuinse
Apis mellifera; Tetragonisca angustula; Trigona amazonensis
lampírido, luciérnaga (Peru), añañahui (Peru), cocuyo   (attributed Taino origin)
Also gan̥ooi. There are many kinds.

Black m. that flies night and day; cf. 03.586. Small m. that flies by night is i'n̥aro; large m. that flies at night is suede'hai; side-'n̥ai; a big m. is i'n̥aro ke'den̥a; m. that flies at dawn and at dusk is se'da-bia; sue'da-bia.
'Black widow s. is i'moi-n̥a; s. that spins webs in trails is ke'nee-ŋe'tee.
Mono Lanudo Común, Choro, Churucu, mono choro (Peru), mono lanudo cafe, barrigudo de Humboldt
mono negro (Peru), Machín Negro, Maicero Cachón, mono maicero
Machín Blanco, mono blanco, Maicero Cariblanco, mono blanco (Peru)
Machin Blanco, Mono Araña de Vientre Amarillo, maquisapa (Peru), braceadora (Colombia)
Lobo Grande de Río, nutria gigante, lutria
Nutria, Lobo de Agua, lobito de rio, perro de agua (Colombia)
sajino, pecarí de collar, jabalf, Javelina, Saíno, Pecarí de Collar
Guatusa Negra, Añuje, Agutí (black-rumped), picure, jochi colorado
Guatín, Punchana, curi, picurito rabudo, picurito rabilargo
Cuniculus paca (Agouti paca is sometimes used as well although cuniculus is the correct term.)
Means b. of rope; a b. of palm fronds is o'rai in̥aak o'ho.
abalorio, mostacilla, cuenta, gota, puca; necklace=collar
Refers to big, black seed-beads; small black seed-beads is pu'ru-i.
To make the b. is ĩ'tereʔ. To make his own bed or position of sleeping is oo y-ihoga-'di, cf. 07.210.
Used to be used by Tukanoan peoples (and others?), sound carried for long distances

Refers to a lower-level healer; in RN region, most older men in a village have this capacity, and command a repertoire of healing spells. Power is primarily for good, whereas the true shaman is capable of malignant acts as well.
malignant forest spirit, covered with long hair, feet turned backward; in Upper Rio Negro region
espíritu malo, espíritu maligno, fantasma, demonio
Also oo du'paa-de ihiʔ, means 'to make yourself a god'.
carrizo, zampoñas, flautas de pan, rondadora
A k. in a sheath is ka'ričaai; kee'seei ka'ričaai 03.655.

The b. prepared for use in a ball is di'rin̥e; b. from the hive and chewed is du'kuudaai; black b. of the 'golden bee' is ii'beye; black edible b. of the 'suro bee' is kũtere ke'de-n̥a-i. Black or red b. that is sticky is čaake'do; čaae'do. In the N̥upedo

Domestic bee h. is a'ka 08.530; a cell of wild h. is du'kuu-pie; abundance of h. is ku'terĩ-'pepie; h. brought to camp is i'saa-i 11.140; h. guarded is hoo'yaa-i; wasp h. is 'asago; tree in which they hope will yield h. is 'tode; h. water kũ'ter-ota'di, l
The latter is 'braided rope'. 'Lasso' is 'enuhe-n̥ai; 'feather rope' is ibota'ye.
yurupari, jurupari (or any flutes forbidden to women)
a ritual complex in various parts of Amazonia involving sacred flutes/trumpets, forbidden to women.
fetiche, encanto, filtro de amor,  pusanga
Respectively: 12.080, 01.510, 12.470; plural form. Also gaa'tan̥o-keei; and 'gee-ode 'ueečaai, means 'the other side of the clouds'.
Means 'different corn plant'; sugar cane plant is n̥aaka'raai, cf. 08. 510.
A 'pistol' is po'kaa kata'de 12.590; 'rifle' is po'kaa; po'kaa garahaa-'dieʔ 02.458; 'shot-gun' is po'kaa ke'ruu-a 12.550.

Ground s. is e'čo u'rui, lit. salt dust; cf. 'flour' 05.550. A chunk of s. is e'čo-i i'ribi-di; to sprinkle s. on the food u'n̥ute-gaay; s. crystals ũri'arõi ga'n̥ui, lit. a picture of molartooth 04.272.
currently limited to certain groups (favoring h-g orientation, e.g. Nadahup) within RN region
esp. for fanning a cooking fire
A one-day hunt, is baai; 'baage; an overnight hunt is moo-i; moo-'ŋe 04.610.
esp. for grating manioc, but can be used for other things as well
grid of sticks for smoking meat or placing objects (shelf)
pilón, mano de mortero, mazo, moledor
Also means 'dust' 01.213; also rice hull, 05.810. 'Palm nut flour' is nami-'ni; wheat or manioc f. is 'kučaa u'rui; fine corn f. is ti'ki-n̥ai.
usually manioc; agriculture, but also can be made from certain wild seeds/fruits
tipiti, matafrio, sebucán, exprimador, prensa para yuca
word of Tupi origin; agriculture: specifically for squeezing poison out of manioc
hunting, currently is falling out of use in Vaupés region, associated primarily with h-g groups (but this may be recent?)
agriculture? commonly used for sifting dry manioc flour
can refer to worms; more generic
if different word from top grinding stone
use word for top grinding stone if different from bottom stone
